subject: Re: [junit] byte can be bigger than 127 ...
msgSnippet: ... Considering the comments in your test, (i.e. Byte and Short violate the expected result, but Integer doesn t) my guess is that for some reason your
messageBody:
Berin Loritsch wrote:
> Berin Loritsch wrote:
>
>>Magnús Þór Torfason wrote:
>>
>>
>>>You are getting exactly the results I would have expected. The test SHOULD
>>>fail. My problem is that it doesn't fail on my systems.
>>>
>>>Sorry that I did not specify my system type before:


Considering the comments in your test, (i.e. Byte and Short violate the
expected result, but Integer doesn't) my guess is that for some reason
your variables are being promoted to integer values durring addition and
subtraction.

My advise is to double-check the variable names. Make sure you are
comparing classByte with Byte.MAX_VALUE.

Also make sure that you are running an old version of the class. It is
possible that you caught an instance of the variable name mistake, but
didn't recompile the class. Remember that Javac is optimizing--it won't
compile a class if it already exists. remove the compiled class,
recompile and retest.




--

"They that give up essential liberty to obtain a little temporary safety
deserve neither liberty nor safety."
- Benjamin Franklin
